liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The woman was only known to police through "a minor matter a number of years ago".

children.content: The woman was only known to police through "a minor matter a number of years ago".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A tactical police team entered the unit to remove the woman, but Peter McKenna has confirmed "specialist negotiators" were also on scene. "We don't have any information at this time about mental health issues," he says. "However that will certainly form part of this investigation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Specialist negotiators' on scene

children.content: A tactical police team entered the unit to remove the woman, but Peter McKenna has confirmed "specialist negotiators" were also on scene.
"We don't have any information at this time about mental health issues," he says.
"However that will certainly form part of this investigation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We will be retrieving all available evidence to ensure this is thoroughly investigation, independently reviewed and put before the state coroner," says Peter McKenna.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Significant' investigation expected

children.content: "We will be retrieving all available evidence to ensure this is thoroughly investigation, independently reviewed and put before the state coroner," says Peter McKenna.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Minister for Indigenous Australians, Linda Burney, says it's "simply wrong" to say colonisation has no ongoing, negative impacts on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It's in response to Shadow Indigenous Australians Minister Jacinta Nampijinpa Price telling the National Press Club yesterday that she believed Indigenous Australians were not being negatively affected by colonisation. Ms Burney says what Senator Price said was "shocking", "offensive" and " a betrayal of many families living with the consequences of the Stolen Generations". "The idea that colonisation, in any country where there's been a colonisation process, doesn't have long and far-reaching effects is simply wrong," she says Attorney-General Mark Dreyfus told Radio National the No campaign strategy was to "ignore the proposal that is on the ballot paper". "She is doing what the No campaign has done for many, many months, which is to talk about anything other than this referendum," he says. Federal Opposition Leader Peter Dutton was asked by Channel Nine if he agreed with her views. "Firstly, she's a brave Indigenous woman, and we either accept that people have views, a broad range of views, or we don't," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Price 'talking about anything other than this referendum': attorney-general

featuredLink.title: 'This referendum is about the future': Mark Dreyfus  - ABC listen

props.alt: Jacinta Price next to a sign which says National Press Club of Australia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While most people would be stoked to run one marathon in their life, Sydney man Chris Turnbull has been doing that twice a day, every day, for 39 days. Turnbull left Perth on August 8 seeking to break the record for running from Perth to Sydney. He aims to finish in Manly, Sydney, tomorrow. Speaking from the Hume Highway in Marulan, he told News Breakfast he wanted a "real life-sized adventure". "I wanted to meet the people, see the places of our diverse country," he said. "I also wanted to test out my body and see how fast I could do it."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Man running two marathons a day from Perth to Sydney in world record attempt

children.content: While most people would be stoked to run one marathon in their life, Sydney man Chris Turnbull has been doing that twice a day, every day, for 39 days.
Turnbull left Perth on August 8 seeking to break the record for running from Perth to Sydney. He aims to finish in Manly, Sydney, tomorrow.
Speaking from the Hume Highway in Marulan, he told News Breakfast he wanted a "real life-sized adventure".
"I wanted to meet the people, see the places of our diverse country," he said.
"I also wanted to test out my body and see how fast I could do it."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The school holiday rush is underway at Melbourne Airport, where staff are bracing for the busiest day since the start of the pandemic. ABC reporter Stephanie Ferrier is at Melbourne Airport this morning. "It's very congested here already, with up to 114,000 travellers expected today," she says. "Top destinations include Sydney, Brisbane, Indonesia and New Zealand. Passengers say there've been big queues at the car parks and check-in desks but they're focussed on their holidays." Meanwhile, at Brisbane Airport, therapy dogs have been brought in to help with travel stress in the crowds. Friday, September 29 is forecast to be Brisbane airport's busiest day post-COVID, with 70,000 passengers expected to pass through. Domestic travel is expected to be 6 per cent busier than the same time last year, with 1,287,000 passengers forecast to travel around the country — this is 92 per cent of pre-COVID 2019 levels.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brisbane and Melbourne airports brace for busiest days post-COVID

children.content: The school holiday rush is underway at Melbourne Airport, where staff are bracing for the busiest day since the start of the pandemic.
ABC reporter Stephanie Ferrier is at Melbourne Airport this morning.

Meanwhile, at Brisbane Airport, therapy dogs have been brought in to help with travel stress in the crowds.

Friday, September 29 is forecast to be Brisbane airport's busiest day post-COVID, with 70,000 passengers expected to pass through.
Domestic travel is expected to be 6 per cent busier than the same time last year, with 1,287,000 passengers forecast to travel around the country — this is 92 per cent of pre-COVID 2019 levels.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ACCC has issued a draft determination proposing to deny authorisation for Qantas and China Eastern Airlines and their related entities (including Jetstar) to continue coordinating operations between Australia and mainland China. Qantas and China Eastern are seeking authorisation for an Extended Joint Coordination Agreement that enables them to coordinate passenger and cargo transport operations between Australia and China until the end of March 2024. An agreement for coordination between two key competitors may breach competition laws. The ACCC can only authorise these agreements if the public benefits from the coordination outweigh the harm to competition. “At this stage we are not satisfied that the likely harm to competition from Qantas and China Eastern’s proposed coordination would be outweighed by any potential benefits,” ACCC Commissioner Anna Brakey said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACCC to deny coordination between Qantas and China Eastern

children.content: The ACCC has issued a draft determination proposing to deny authorisation for Qantas and China Eastern Airlines and their related entities (including Jetstar) to continue coordinating operations between Australia and mainland China.

Qantas and China Eastern are seeking authorisation for an Extended Joint Coordination Agreement that enables them to coordinate passenger and cargo transport operations between Australia and China until the end of March 2024.

An agreement for coordination between two key competitors may breach competition laws. The ACCC can only authorise these agreements if the public benefits from the coordination outweigh the harm to competition.

“At this stage we are not satisfied that the likely harm to competition from Qantas and China Eastern’s proposed coordination would be outweighed by any potential benefits,” ACCC Commissioner Anna Brakey said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has opened up sharply higher, led by strong gains in mining and banking stocks. The ASX 200 was up 1.3 per cent to 7,281 potins, by 10:10am AEST. Most sectors were higher. The education sector was the only sector that was in the red at open.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens up

children.content: The Australian share market has opened up sharply higher, led by strong gains in mining and banking stocks.
The ASX 200 was
up 1.3 per cent
to 7,281 potins, by 10:10am AEST.
Most sectors were higher. The education sector was the only sector that was in the red at open.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Woodside has been temporarily blocked from moving ahead with part of a major gas project off WA's northern coast. The company was in July given approval to carry out seismic testing, which involves releasing powerful blasts of air towards the ocean floor to search for gas, for its Scarborough project. Scientists have warned seismic blasting can have subtle but critical effects on marine life, like depleting feeding areas for whales. That approval is being challenged by the Environmental Defenders Office (EDO) which brought a case on behalf of Mardudhunera woman Raelene Cooper. She is claiming Woodside did not properly consult with her and other traditional owners before it was given approval to carry out the testing by the National Offshore Petroleum Safety and Environmental Management Authority (NOPSEMA). Read more from Keane Bourke .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woodside temporarily blocked from carrying out seismic testing

featuredLink.title: Woodside temporarily blocked from carrying out seismic testing at major gas project off WA coast

with part of a major gas project off WA's northern coast.
The company was in July given approval to carry out seismic testing, which involves releasing powerful blasts of air towards the ocean floor to search for gas, for its Scarborough project.
Scientists have warned seismic blasting can have
subtle but critical effects on marine life,
like depleting feeding areas for whales.
That approval is being challenged by the Environmental Defenders Office (EDO) which brought a case on behalf of Mardudhunera woman Raelene Cooper.

She is claiming Woodside did not properly consult with her and other traditional owners before it was given approval to carry out the testing by the National Offshore Petroleum Safety and Environmental Management Authority (NOPSEMA).

Keane Bourke
